prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC0424 and NGC0526A
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Search for outflows and inflow motions in the centres of NGC 0424 and NGC 0526, Band 7 observations

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The sensitivity requested is dictated by the expected flux of the CO(3-2) emission in the nuclear region of the AGN and starburst galaxies in the sample. We have assumed a CO-to-H2 conversion factor of 0.5 x 10^20 cm^-2/(K km s^-1) valid for star-forming galaxies (Bolatto et al. 2013), a beam dilution factor of 5-10, and a CO(3-2)/CO(1-0) ratio of 2 (Matsushita et al. 2004; Boone et al. 2011), to compute the detectable molecular mass. In our survey, we require an RMS sensitivity of 0.9 mJy/beam, a spectral resolution of 1 km/s and a total bandwidth of 1650 km/s. The data will be smoothed to ~10 km/s in those cases with a lower S/N ratio.
With the above settings and assuming a line FWHM of 150 km/s, we will be able to detect the CO emission at 5 sigma over a bandwidth of 50 km/s, which corresponds to molecular masses ranging from 2 x 10^6 solar masses (at a distance of D = 40 Mpc) to 2 x 10^7 solar masses (at D = 126 Mpc). Only one target galaxy (IRASF05189-2524) has a larger distance of D = 181 Mpc, where the detection limit will be at ~3.5 x 10^7 solar masses.
Simultaneously with CO(3-2) we will observe HCO+(4-3) and SiO(8-7). These two transitions can be useful to study dense and/or shocked gas that might be associated to the outflows. In NGC1068 the CO(3-2)/HCO+(4-3) ratio show values between 1.2 and 40 (Garcia-Burillo et al. 2014). The SiO(8-7) line will trace the shocks in the dense gas. The exact line flux is uncertain, but we estimate a rough value of HCO+(4-3)/SiO(8-7) ~ 0.2 based on lower transitions of SiO observed in the starburst galaxy NGC253 (Meier et al. 2015).

The main science driver is to measure the CO (3-2) transition, which may have line widths between 50-150 km/s, depending on whether it is measured in the outflow or the inner parts of the galaxy (Combes et al. 2013, 2014). While the predicted line width for the outflow is 150 km/s, the CO emission from the galaxy will be narrower. We request a spectral resolution of ~1 km/s and a total bandwidth of ~1650 km/s for the CO line, in order to resolve the kinematics of the lines in the inner region of the galaxies and trace inflow motions. For the weaker outflow emission we will average the spectra to ~50 km/s in order to achieve the requested sensitivity. In addition, we added a TDM spectral window to observe the far-IR continuum produced by cold dust.

The ~18 arcsec FoV of the requested Band 7 ALMA observations is sufficient to fully cover emission on a scale from 4 to 16 kpc at galaxy distances from 40 to 180 Mpc. This is enough to map the circumnuclear regions where outflows and inflow motions occur for the Seyfert ans starburst galaxies in our sample, therefore only a single pointing is required per source. We request an angular resolution of 0.09", in order to spatially resolve outflows with ~100 pc extension at the maximum distance of our sample (D = 180 Mpc). To limit the number of antenna configurations, we request 0.11" for low elevation targets (declinations > +15 deg.). This change does not affect the science case since ~100 pc structures will still be spatially resolved with a beam size of 0.11" for these targets. The most extended structures we expect to recover will be around 1.4 arcsec on sky, corresponding to 300-1200 pc for the distances of 40-180 Mpc.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Search for outflows and inflows in the centre of NGC 1363, Band 7 observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:

The data will be smoothed to ~10 km/s in those cases with a lower S/N ratio.
With the above settings and assuming a line FWHM of 150 km/s, we will be able to detect the CO emission at 5 sigma over a bandwidth of 50 km/s, which corresponds to molecular masses ranging from 2 x 10^6 solar masses (at a distance of D = 40 Mpc) to 2 x 10^7 solar masses (at D = 126 Mpc). prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We will observe CO(3-2) in the first fully representative sample of AGN and starburst galaxies drawn from the complete well-studied 12micron all-sky sample, to study both AGN feeding and AGN/Starburst feedback, and make the first comprehensive measure of the global impact of these processes at the current epoch. We will detect molecular outflows down to 2e6 to 4e7 Msun (depending on distance), and also measure the orbital velocity perturbations to estimate the angular momentum loss that drives inflows. We will observe 29 bright galaxies which, when added to existing archival observations, will provide a total complete sample of 45 galaxies (32 Seyfert and 13 starburst galaxies). We will compare the mass loss rates in AGN-driven outflows with the gas reservoir to estimate timescales for depletion, and how they depend on specific galaxy properties. Our complete sample will yield the first statistics for the velocities, mass and energy rates, covering fractions and duty cycles of these gas flows for the entire population of AGN and starbursts in the local universe, a critical unknown in theories of galaxy formation.
